articles.headline: Pentagon Invites Kremlin to Link Missile Systems
articles.snippet: The U.S. is offering Russia a new package of incentives to drop its opposition to U.S. missile defense sites in Poland and the Czech Republic.
articles.abstract: The U.S. is offering Russia a new package of incentives to drop its opposition to U.S. missile defense sites in Poland and the Czech Republic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20 — The Bush administration is offering Russia a new package of incentives to drop its strong opposition to American missile defense sites in Poland and the Czech Republic, including an invitation to begin linking some American and Russian antimissile systems, according to senior administration and military officials.

articles.headline: China Adds Billionaires With I.P.O.
articles.snippet: Country Garden’s public offering is just the latest symbol of China’s meteoric rise, and the country’s continuing stock market fever.
articles.abstract: Country Garden’s public offering is just the latest symbol of China’s meteoric rise, and the country’s continuing stock market fever.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, April 20 — The 52-year-old Chinese farmer turned developer is as plain as the company’s English name: Country Garden. But there was nothing ordinary about his company’s debut Friday on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

articles.headline: A New Twist on Snooping at Wal-Mart
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart’s chief took the unusual step of releasing portions of a former employee’s sworn testimony that denied surveillance on shareholders and employees.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart’s chief took the unusual step of releasing portions of a former employee’s sworn testimony that denied surveillance on shareholders and employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: A former Wal-Mart computer technician, who asserted that company employees eavesdropped on board meetings and conducted clandestine surveillance on shareholders, has reversed himself and denied both claims in sworn testimony, the giant retailer said yesterday.

articles.headline: Auditioning in a Video Résumé
articles.snippet: Executives, job seekers, college applicants and others are seeking help with anything from basic blogs to podcasts.
articles.abstract: Executives, job seekers, college applicants and others are seeking help with anything from basic blogs to podcasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Ronald R. Rawitt, a New York City psychiatrist, is shy. When he gets nervous, he slips into “aha” and “um” mode. As someone who often lectures, this is a problem. It is also an issue because he is looking for work, and he worries that he is not coming off as forcefully as he would like.

articles.headline: Growing Unrest Posing a Threat to Nigerian Oil
articles.snippet: Increasing violence has rippled across energy markets, contributing to higher prices and tighter supplies.
articles.abstract: Increasing violence has rippled across energy markets, contributing to higher prices and tighter supplies.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT HARCOURT, Nigeria — There are few safe places left for oil companies in the Niger Delta, the epicenter of this country’s petroleum industry.

articles.headline: U.S. Rules Made Killer Ineligible to Purchase Gun
articles.snippet: Under federal law, the Virginia Tech gunman should have been prohibited from buying a gun after he was declared to be a danger to himself.
articles.abstract: Under federal law, the Virginia Tech gunman should have been prohibited from buying a gun after he was declared to be a danger to himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20 — Under federal law, the Virginia Tech gunman Seung-Hui Cho should have been prohibited from buying a gun after a Virginia court declared him to be a danger to himself in late 2005 and sent him for psychiatric treatment, a state official and several legal experts said Friday.

articles.headline: Sallie Mae Offers a Lesson on Cashing In
articles.snippet: Sallie Mae was once an institution where profits took a back seat to performing a public good. That, alas, is no longer the case.
articles.abstract: Sallie Mae was once an institution where profits took a back seat to performing a public good. That, alas, is no longer the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aren’t you just fuming about that Sallie Mae deal?

articles.headline: The Perils of Being Suddenly Rich
articles.snippet: David Hayden, a dot-com entrepreneur, put his faith in investment bankers who have now gone after him for all he’s worth — and more.
articles.abstract: David Hayden, a dot-com entrepreneur, put his faith in investment bankers who have now gone after him for all he’s worth — and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: In many ways, David Hayden is the ideal entrepreneur. While still in elementary school in a suburb east of San Francisco he published a newspaper, and before graduating from college he had his own construction business. He has seen his Internet start-ups — first Magellan, then Critical Path — soar and he has seen them crash.

articles.headline: 3 Suspects Talk After Iraqi Soldiers Do Dirty Work
articles.snippet: Beatings of suspects by Iraqi soldiers, which appear to be widespread, are a largely undiscussed dilemma for American troops.
articles.abstract: Beatings of suspects by Iraqi soldiers, which appear to be widespread, are a largely undiscussed dilemma for American troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 21 — Out here in what the soldiers call Baghdad’s wild west, sometimes the choices are all bad.

articles.headline: 50% Good News Is the Bad News in Russian Radio
articles.snippet: The Russian government is expanding its control over the media and demanding more upbeat news.
articles.abstract: The Russian government is expanding its control over the media and demanding more upbeat news.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, April 21 — At their first meeting with journalists since taking over Russia’s largest independent radio news network, the managers had startling news of their own: from now on, they said, at least 50 percent of the reports about Russia must be “positive.”

articles.headline: Settlers’ Defiance Reflects Postwar Israeli Changes
articles.snippet: The war with Hezbollah has left Israel’s prime minister too politically weak to challenge newly emboldened settlers.
articles.abstract: The war with Hezbollah has left Israel’s prime minister too politically weak to challenge newly emboldened settlers.
articles.lead_paragraph: HEBRON, West Bank, April 20 — One night last month, 100 Jewish settlers marched down the main road here with little more than a stack of sleeping bags and claimed a vacant four-story building in the middle of an Arab neighborhood.

articles.headline: Before Deadly Rage, a Life Consumed by a Troubling Silence
articles.snippet: Seung-Hui Cho was sullen and brooding from a young age. He acted, a neighbor recalled, “like he had a broken heart.”
articles.abstract: Seung-Hui Cho was sullen and brooding from a young age. He acted, a neighbor recalled, “like he had a broken heart.”
articles.lead_paragraph: From the beginning, he did not talk. Not to other children, not to his own family. Everyone saw this. In Seoul, South Korea, where Seung-Hui Cho grew up, his mother agonized over his sullen, brooding behavior and empty face. Talk, she just wanted him to talk.

articles.headline: Mortgages’ Mystery: The Losses
articles.snippet: The losses on subprime loans are there, but are unrecorded.
articles.abstract: The losses on subprime loans are there, but are unrecorded.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVE you noticed how quickly financial market crises come and go nowadays? Refco, the venerable commodities firm, disintegrated in a week in 2005 and last year’s demise of Amaranth, a $6 billion hedge fund, took about the same amount of time. It is a measure of how deep and wide the money pools are today that the billions lost at these institutions amounted to no more than a blip on a screen.

articles.headline: Giuliani Shifts His Tone on Immigration
articles.snippet: In contrast to his years as New York’s mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani is now taking a tough stance on immigration.
articles.abstract: In contrast to his years as New York’s mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani is now taking a tough stance on immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, April 16 — Rudolph W. Giuliani is a long way from Ellis Island.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Sam Roberts

articles.headline: Goal! He Spends It on Beckham
articles.snippet: Phil Anschutz bets on star power, and everything else.
articles.abstract: Phil Anschutz bets on star power, and everything else.
articles.lead_paragraph: Denver

articles.headline: Africa’s Crisis of Democracy
articles.snippet: Analysts said the Nigerian vote showed that many African voters are steadily losing confidence in their democracies.
articles.abstract: Analysts said the Nigerian vote showed that many African voters are steadily losing confidence in their democracies.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANO, Nigeria, April 22 — Nigeria’s troubled presidential election, which came under fire on Sunday from local and international observers and was rejected by two leading opposition candidates, represents a significant setback for democracy in sub-Saharan Africa at a time when voters in countries across the continent are becoming more disillusioned with the way democracy is practiced.

articles.headline: Carson-Era Humor, Post-Colbert
articles.snippet: Rich Little was hired for this year’s White House Correspondents’ dinner to help the audience forget last year when Stephen Colbert opened both barrels on all parties.
articles.abstract: Rich Little was hired for this year’s White House Correspondents’ dinner to help the audience forget last year when Stephen Colbert opened both barrels on all parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year’s White House Correspondents’ Association dinner was held Saturday night, and everywhere you looked in the ballroom at the Hilton Washington lame ducks were taking wing.

articles.headline: Philadelphia Journalism’s New Order
articles.snippet: At The Philadelphia Inquirer, a joint venture with an advertiser that in other times might have raised questions is being rethought.
articles.abstract: At The Philadelphia Inquirer, a joint venture with an advertiser that in other times might have raised questions is being rethought.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Starting next week, The Philadelphia Inquirer will run a new column called PhillyInc., written by Inquirer reporters and editors, on the first page of its business section.

articles.headline: Debates Losing a Bit of Luster in a Big Field
articles.snippet: Aides to the major candidates have concluded that the large number of debates has become a hindrance.
articles.abstract: Aides to the major candidates have concluded that the large number of debates has become a hindrance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 22 — The last time Jonathan Prince checked, there were nearly 40 requests for John Edwards, the Democratic presidential candidate for whom he works, to appear at a candidate debate or forum.

articles.headline: PC Games, Once Down, Show Signs of Rebound
articles.snippet: PC video game titles, once the mainstay of video gaming, are showing signs of a comeback.
articles.abstract: PC video game titles, once the mainstay of video gaming, are showing signs of a comeback.
articles.lead_paragraph: Navigating the aisles of a GameStop video game store in Midtown Manhattan, Bennett Kirschner passed by the latest titles for consoles like Microsoft’s Xbox 360, Sony’s PlayStation 2 and 3, and Nintendo’s runaway hit, the Wii — all lit and displayed like best-selling novels.

articles.headline: Former Media Executives Give New Life to ‘Blank Check’ Corporations
articles.snippet: An obscure financing technique called “special purpose acquisition corporations,” or SPACs, are increasingly being used as an alternative to private equity.
articles.abstract: An obscure financing technique called “special purpose acquisition corporations,” or SPACs, are increasingly being used as an alternative to private equity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Time was that former media executives were offered consulting contracts, partnerships at private equity firms or book deals. Now, they are being offered a blank check.

articles.headline: A Maestro of Investments in the Style of Buffett
articles.snippet: Warren E. Buffett’s successor will probably be a lot like Louis Simpson, who has overseen the investment portfolio of Geico.
articles.abstract: Warren E. Buffett’s successor will probably be a lot like Louis Simpson, who has overseen the investment portfolio of Geico.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Warren E. Buffett is hardly a man of mystery.

articles.headline: Voting Sets Up Left-Right Duel to Lead France
articles.snippet: The presidential election is now a classic battle between two candidates with competing visions for France.
articles.abstract: The presidential election is now a classic battle between two candidates with competing visions for France.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 22 — Nicolas Sarkozy, the conservative, and Ségolène Royal, the Socialist, won the first round of the presidential election on Sunday, setting up a classic left-right contest next month between two candidates with competing visions of how to govern France.
